unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked what it's *really* like working in the emergency room in India. Buckle up, beta testers, because it's not always like you see on TV.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked what it is really like working in the emergency room in India. Buckle up, beta testers, because it is not always like you see on T-V.

unnormalised: First off, forget the dramatic walk-ins with single gunshot wounds. Nah, bhai. We get a spectrum. From the "my tummy hurts since yesterday" crowd at 2 AM (yes, really) to actual, honest-to-god emergencies. And sometimes, it's hard to tell the difference until you've spent 20 minutes listening to a detailed history of their digestive issues dating back to 1998. I once had a guy come in because he thought he *might* have a paper cut. Paper cut! It was microscopic. My chai addiction is probably a bigger emergency, tbh.
normalised: First off, forget the dramatic walk-ins with single gunshot wounds. Nah, bhai. We get a spectrum. From the "my tummy hurts since yesterday" crowd at two A-M (yes, really) to actual, honest-to-god emergencies. And sometimes, it is hard to tell the difference until you have spent twenty minutes listening to a detailed history of their digestive issues dating back to one thousand nine hundred and ninety eight. I once had a guy come in because he thought he might have a paper cut. Paper cut! It was microscopic. My chai addiction is probably a bigger emergency, to be honest.

unnormalised: Then there's the diagnostic challenges. Our MRI machine, bless its ancient soul, might be down for "routine maintenance" (read: the technician's gone to his village for a festival). So, you're relying on your clinical acumen, your stethoscope, and maybe a lucky guess. Oh, and the collective wisdom of your senior resident who’s probably on their 36th hour shift. Good luck interpreting that ECG with shaky hands! Yesterday, Dr. Sharma almost diagnosed a perfectly healthy patient with Stage 4 something-or-other. Turned out, the machine needed recalibration!
normalised: Then there is the diagnostic challenges. Our M-R-I machine, bless its ancient soul, might be down for "routine maintenance" (read: the technician has gone to his village for a festival). So, you are relying on your clinical acumen, your stethoscope, and maybe a lucky guess. Oh, and the collective wisdom of your senior resident who is probably on their thirty sixth hour shift. Good luck interpreting that E-C-G with shaky hands! Yesterday, Doctor Sharma almost diagnosed a perfectly healthy patient with Stage four something-or-other. Turned out, the machine needed recalibration!

unnormalised: And let's talk paperwork. So. Much. Paperwork. It’s like we’re single-handedly keeping the paper industry afloat. You gotta document everything. Every cough, every sneeze, every questionable rash. "Patient claims headache began at 14:30 hrs. Denies fever. Vital signs stable-ish." I swear, I spend more time writing than actually treating patients. My handwriting is so bad now it could probably be its own emergency situation.
normalised: And let us talk paperwork. So. Much. Paperwork. It is like we are single-handedly keeping the paper industry afloat. You got to document everything. Every cough, every sneeze, every questionable rash. "Patient claims headache began at fourteen thirty hours. Denies fever. Vital signs stable-ish." I swear, I spend more time writing than actually treating patients. My handwriting is so bad now it could probably be its own emergency situation.

unnormalised: But here's the honest truth, amidst the chaos and the chronic back pain (thanks, uncomfortable hospital beds!), there are moments when you actually feel like a hero. When you stabilise that kid after a road accident (Rs. 2000 helmet might have saved his life), or when you catch a silent heart attack just in time. Those are the moments that make it all worthwhile. So, yeah, it's a bit mad, a bit messy, and a lot exhausting, but it’s also kinda the best job in the world. Just bring your sense of humour, a strong bladder, and maybe a lifetime supply of chai. You’ll need it.
